snippet: Students say they have been inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement and the protests at the University of Missouri to demand their universities provide a safe space for students of color.
abstract: Students at colleges across United States take part in protests against racial inequalities suffered on campus, inspired by success of demonstrations at University of Missouri and Black Lives Matter movement; Yale University, Ithaca College and Claremont McKenna College in California are among campuses where students are publicly sharing racially charged experiences.

byline.original: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS and JESS BIDGOOD
byline.contributor: Jeff Stein contributed reporting from Ithaca, N.Y.

lead_paragraph: Students say they have been inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement and the protests at the University of Missouri to demand their universities provide a safe space for students of color.

headline.main: Racial Discrimination Protests Ignite at Colleges Across the U.S.
headline.print_headline: Racial Discrimination Demonstrations Spread at Universities Across the U.S.
